newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek PM Simitis wants tough "can do" cabinet.
newsitem.headline: Greek PM Simitis wants tough "can do" cabinet.

text.p: Greece's socialist Prime Minister Costas Simitis, fresh from an election win, was assembling a tough new ministerial team on Monday to push through foreign and economic policy changes.
Simitis has vowed to turn Greece's sprawling and inefficient bureaucracy into a "hands-on" meritocracy where anyone who fails to work hard will be replaced.

The no-nonsense approach is a far cry from his predecessor, the late socialist party founder Andreas Papandreou, who was renowned for dancing until the early hours and publicly ordering his finance minister to "give it all away".
In his short time since inheriting Papandreou's mantle in January, Simitis has worked hard to convince the United States and the European Union that a new era in relations was at hand.
Western diplomats seemed delighted Simitis had come through with 162 deputies in the 300-seat parliament, saying it meant stability and a determination to change Greece's laggardly Balkan ways.

"He is methodical and has a step-by-step approach," a Western diplomat said. "He has done an exceptional job in his first eight months by reknitting tattered relations with the European Union and the United States."
EU diplomats expected Simitis to be more active in pushing his foreign policy and economic reforms, and applauded him for his non-confrontational approach.

Simitis joined the socialist party in 1974 when it was set up after a brutal seven-year military junta fell. He has served in every Papandreou cabinet but remained largely in the shadows until his one-time mentor fell ill last year.

Then Simitis, 60, replaced the ailing Papandreou as premier in January, scored a leadership victory to run the party after Papandreou died in June and finally cemented his grip on power by leading the socialists to a solid election victory.
"With such a strong victory, all leadership battles are finished in our party," said a former senior socialist official.
Simitis is an intensely private man who seemed ill-at-ease with the public attention of campaigning. He has turned his back on the histrionics and unpredictable shifts of Papandreou.
While Papandreou's flamboyant antics delighted many Greeks, they left the country alienated from its main Western allies and weakened in the international arena.
Simitis, who trained in Germany and Britain as an economist and lawyer, has called for a "new era" of sacrifice and work to earn the respect of European Union partners.

He is the first fresh face to lead Greece in 20 years and the most pro-European and pro-Western leader in a long spell. He is comfortable hobnobbing with EU leaders in Brussels and speaks English, French and German with ease.
After receiving a mandate to form his new government, he set to work with a half dozen close advisers. He is expected to name the cabinet he wants and reject negotiations over who gets what.
"My colleagues and I have the huge responsibility of leading Greece into the 21st century," he said.

Defence Minister Gerassimos Arsenis is almost certain to go, partly for pushing for a $10 billion military build-up. Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos is another possible departure but he would go to another ministry, perhaps transport.
